The Dow watched practically all of its gains since President Trump’s inauguration </span><span><a href="https://apnews.com/dc2fb16770ee45526c137d25a102a9f1?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">evaporate</a></span><span>, and the circuit breaker was called into action again to give the S&P a 15-minute breather.</span>

Both benchmarks (WTI and Brent) are on pace for their </span></span><span><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/18/oil-plummets-to-near-18-year-low-on-pace-for-worst-month-ever.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">worst month ever</a></span><span><span>. </span></span><span>
</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>

<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
ECONOMY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/18/save-economies-countries-put-recessions?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
World Economies Go Full Turtle
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="World turtle" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yNjMvd29ybGRfdHVydGxlLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Francis Scialabba</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">To save their economies over the long run, countries around the world are actively putting themselves into recessions.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Here's why: </strong>We don’t live in <em>Ready Player One</em>’s<em> </em>virtual universe just yet, which means humans still generate trillions in economic activity by coming into close, physical contact with one another—sitting at restaurants, assembling auto parts, traveling on planes, getting haircuts. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But public health officials stress that to slow the spread of the coronavirus, we must all maintain a safe distance from each other, even if we’re healthy. That doesn’t square with our economy’s structure. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0"><strong style="color:#000">The only solution for governments? </strong></h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Shut it down.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Hedge fund manager Bill Ackman: </strong></span><span>“Mr. President, the only answer is to shut down the country for the next 30 days and close the borders. Tell all Americans that you are putting us on an extended Spring Break at home with family,” he </span><span><a href="https://twitter.com/BillAckman/status/1240246799652335622?s=20&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">tweeted</a></span><span> yesterday.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Gregory Daco, chief U.S. economist at Oxford Economics: </strong></span><span>“The more rapidly you want to contain the virus, then the more severe the lockdown has to be and the more severe the disruption to economic activity is,” </span><span><a href="https://apnews.com/bd67a54ed7236b4d7d4ce3dcae80db18?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">he told the AP</a></span><span>. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Daco calls it the “Lockdown Paradox.” The steps we need to take to solve the health emergency, such as social distancing, closing shops, and foregoing travel, are the same steps that will plunge us into a recession. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Already, U.S. industries ranging from restaurants to airlines are asking for tens of billions in bailout funds. Soon, millions of perfectly healthy</span><span><em> </em></span><span>Americans will be laid off from perfectly healthy businesses. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">That’s why everything hinges on lawmakers’ response to the economic fallout. Yesterday, the Senate <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/senate-expected-to-pass-bill-offering-free-virus-testing-paid-leave-11584537988?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">overwhelmingly passed</a> a relief bill that includes free testing and an expansion of unemployment insurance. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The Trump administration and congressional leaders are also negotiating an additional $1 trillion stimulus package that may involve direct payments to American households. The question is whether that’ll be enough calories to get us through this self-imposed hibernation. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If it is, we’ll be out of commission for months, and emerge tired and much skinnier. But...at least we’ll emerge.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
WORK
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/18/state-unemployment-websites-see-deluge-visits-driven-coronavirus?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Time to Stop Calling It Funemployment
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Today, the Labor Department will release its weekly report on jobless claims, a proxy for U.S. unemployment. Because our time travel project is still in beta, we don’t know what the report will say, but we have a few indications from <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/state-unemployment-sites-see-increase-in-jobless-claims-11584482492?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">state<span> unemployment benefits sites</span></a> that process unemployment claims. They’re pointing south. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>A rep for New York’s labor department said the spike in claims was similar to the aftermath of 9/11. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>On a typical week, Kentucky processes 2,000 applications. It received over 9,000 on Tuesday alone. </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>“I've never seen anything like this,” a Labor Dept. deputy commissioner told the </span><span><a href="https://www.courant.com/business/hc-biz-unemployment-claims-20200317-uuiam6g2t5b6pczsouacogzenm-story.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Hartford Courant</a></span><span>. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">We should mention—some states have broadened unemployment insurance eligibility to those who are quarantined or don’t have paid leave. That may have driven more Americans to seek unemployment insurance recently.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>Thus far, companies have tried to tiptoe into the coronavirus crisis by furloughing and cutting down hours instead of outright layoffs. But economists say <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/call-it-a-layoff-a-furlough-or-a-cut-shift-americans-are-losing-work-11584550057?mod=hp_lead_pos1&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">layoffs are inevitable</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>today’s report covers last week; we won’t know the extent of this week’s damage until next Thursday.</p>

<tr>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FED
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/18/whats-feds-role-todays-economic-fallout?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
What’s the Fed Got to Do With It?
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Jerome Powell testifying before Congress" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC84MC9qZXJvbWVfcG93ZWxsLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>U.S. Federal Reserve</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The Federal Reserve has <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2020/03/16/economy/federal-reserve-interest-rates-coronavirus/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">taken unprecedented action</a> to stymie the economic fallout of COVID-19...and markets have responded with an unenthusiastic “k.” So what is the central bank’s role in all of this? </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Over to Janet Yellen and Ben Bernanke for the answer. </strong>In a <a href="https://www.ft.com/content/01f267a2-686c-11ea-a3c9-1fe6fedcca75?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Financial Times column</a> yesterday, the former Fed chairs strung together highly technical words to say this: All the Fed can do is soften the inevitable blow.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Because unlike 2008’s financial crisis, this one can’t be solved by monetary policy. Jerome Powell can’t exactly conjure vaccines or time machines.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>That leaves the Fed responsible for 1) making any recession as short as possible and 2) limiting chain reactions.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">How that happens: </strong>The Fed needs to ensure responsible borrowers who fall on temporary hard times can tap into credit when needed. That insulates businesses from needing to lay off workers, which can force families to default on mortgages, which can lead to foreclosure, which can...you get it.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>Keeping borrowing like a gas station dinner—cheap and easy—is important. But <a href="https://www.politico.com/news/2020/03/17/fed-battle-unclog-financial-markets-134282?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">without Congressional backup</a>, the Fed can only do so much.</p>

<tr>

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FOOD
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/18/blue-apron-skyrockets-dismal-day-markets?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Blue Apron: All Those Podcast Ads Are (Finally) Working
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="desks" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yODEvb2ZmaWNlLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Freshome</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, meal kit delivery service <a href="https://finance.yahoo.com/news/blue-apron-stock-more-doubles-174529150.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Blue Apron’s stock</a> (+148%) was the seared salmon swimming upstream in a river of bummer. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The reason?</strong> Restaurants are shutting down just as hoarding shoppers are clearing out some grocery stores. Blue Apron’s meal kits are looking more attractive as a sustenance option...and thus its stock is looking more attractive as a money option. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">The backstory:</strong> Up until recently, Blue Apron was being shunted into the “promising startup that flamed out post-IPO” category with Grubhub and Uber. It went public in 2017 at a nearly $1.9 billion valuation, but even after this week's jump its market cap is down to $216 million. Last year, Blue Apron had to engineer a “reverse split” to support its plummeting stock price.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line: </strong>That maneuver makes <a href="https://techcrunch.com/2020/03/18/why-is-blue-aprons-stock-skyrocketing/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Blue Apron’s resurgence</a> look surgier than it is, and it's unclear whether the company's shaky business pre-virus will find sturdier ground post-virus. Still, you couldn't imagine a better customer base for Blue Apron than a country of hermits. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
COMMUNITY
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/18/brew-readers-share-good-coronavirus-news?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Brew Readers Share Good Coronavirus News
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Jose Andres carrying aid packages " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yMzYvam9zZV9hbmRyZXMuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>BRENDAN SMIALOWSKI/AFP via Getty Images</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">No, that’s not an oxymoron. Inspired by the example of <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/16/jos-andrs-turns-dc-restaurants-community-kitchens?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Chef José Andrés</a>, we asked readers to share stories of people banding together in their own communities. Here are a few responses...</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Brittany in Lawrence, KS: </strong>"<span>The Raven Book Store began a </span><a href="https://www.bookbenefactors.com/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">book benefactor program</a><span> yesterday, delivering curated books to folks who might need them."</span></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><span><strong style="color:#000">Monica: </strong>"People are stepping up and helping animal shelters by applying to be emergency fosters since adoption events are getting canceled and shelters are closing."</span></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><span><strong style="color:#000">Ryan in Los Angeles, CA:</strong> "Something local grocery stores are doing that deserves recognition is some are starting to open their doors an hour earlier for people who are over 60 and those with weakened immune systems."</span></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><span><strong style="color:#000">Anita in College Station, TX:</strong> "There is one restaurant I am very proud of called MESS Waffles, which stated they will feed all school kids with free breakfast."</span></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Chris in South Bend, IN:</strong> "In order to alleviate the struggles for low-income students without access to high-speed internet, the district put wifi-enabled school buses throughout low-income neighborhoods."</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Brew Crew:</strong> We found the website <a href="https://rallyforrestaurants.com/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Rally for Restaurants</a>, which allows you to buy a gift card from a local restaurant and challenge friends to do the same.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Hit reply if you would like to share something positive happening in your local community. </p>

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
FEELING CRABBY
</h3>
</td>

</table>
<img alt="Hermit crab " style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yNjUvaGVybWl0X2NyYWIuanBnIiwiYnVja2V0Ijoib3Nsby1wcm9kdWN0aW9uIiwiZWRpdHMiOnsicmVzaXplIjp7IndpZHRoIjoxMDAwLCJoZWlnaHQiOm51bGx9fX0=">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Pixabay</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Since we’re all hermits these days, we might as well spend some time learning about our cousins: hermit crabs. See if you can answer these questions:</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">1. What best describes a hermit crab’s diet? </p>
<ol style="list-style-type: lower-alpha;">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Carnivorous</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Vegetarian</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Scavenger</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Keto </span></li>
</ol>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">2. What's the max lifespan of the longest-living species of hermit crab? </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">3. Hermit crabs come in two types: terrestrial (land) and aquatic (sea). True or false? </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">4. A hermit crab is a crustacean. Which of the following sea creatures is NOT a crustacean?</p>
<ol style="list-style-type: lower-alpha;">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Barnacle</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Mussel</span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Shrimp </span></li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>Krill </span></li>
</ol>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">If you can pick out the non-crustacean and identify the phylum it belongs to, well, you are probably named Ken Jennings. But let us know if you got it.</p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
</th>
</tr>
</table>

style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nECONOMY \n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/18/save-economies-countries-put-recessions?email={{profile.email}}\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nWorld Economies Go Full Turtle\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"World turtle\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yNjMvd29ybGRfdHVydGxlLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFrancis Scialabba\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eTo save their economies over the long run, countries around the world are actively putting themselves into recessions.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHere's why: \u003c/strong\u003eWe don’t live in \u003cem\u003eReady Player One\u003c/em\u003e’s\u003cem\u003e \u003c/em\u003evirtual universe just yet, which means humans still generate trillions in economic activity by coming into close, physical contact with one another—sitting at restaurants, assembling auto parts, traveling on planes, getting haircuts. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut public health officials stress that to slow the spread of the coronavirus, we must all maintain a safe distance from each other, even if we’re healthy. That doesn’t square with our economy’s structure. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe only solution for governments? \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eShut it down.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHedge fund manager Bill Ackman: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e“Mr. President, the only answer is to shut down the country for the next 30 days and close the borders. Tell all Americans that you are putting us on an extended Spring Break at home with family,” he \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://twitter.com/BillAckman/status/1240246799652335622?s=20\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etweeted\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e yesterday.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eGregory Daco, chief U.S. economist at Oxford Economics: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e“The more rapidly you want to contain the virus, then the more severe the lockdown has to be and the more severe the disruption to economic activity is,” \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://apnews.com/bd67a54ed7236b4d7d4ce3dcae80db18?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehe told the AP\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eDaco calls it the “Lockdown Paradox.” The steps we need to take to solve the health emergency, such as social distancing, closing shops, and foregoing travel, are the same steps that will plunge us into a recession. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eAlready, U.S. industries ranging from restaurants to airlines are asking for tens of billions in bailout funds. Soon, millions of perfectly healthy\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003e \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eAmericans will be laid off from perfectly healthy businesses. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThat’s why everything hinges on lawmakers’ response to the economic fallout. Yesterday, the Senate \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/senate-expected-to-pass-bill-offering-free-virus-testing-paid-leave-11584537988?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eoverwhelmingly passed\u003c/a\u003e a relief bill that includes free testing and an expansion of unemployment insurance. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe Trump administration and congressional leaders are also negotiating an additional $1 trillion stimulus package that may involve direct payments to American households. The question is whether that’ll be enough calories to get us through this self-imposed hibernation. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eIf it is, we’ll be out of commission for months, and emerge tired and much skinnier. But...at least we’ll emerge.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: Funemployment\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eToday, the Labor Department will release its weekly report on jobless claims, a proxy for U.S. unemployment. Because our time travel project is still in beta, we don’t know what the report will say, but we have a few indications from \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/state-unemployment-sites-see-increase-in-jobless-claims-11584482492?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003estate\u003cspan\u003e unemployment benefits sites\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/a\u003e that process unemployment claims. They’re pointing south. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eA rep for New York’s labor department said the spike in claims was similar to the aftermath of 9/11. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eOn a typical week, Kentucky processes 2,000 applications. It received over 9,000 on Tuesday alone. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e“I've never seen anything like this,” a Labor Dept. deputy commissioner told the \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.courant.com/business/hc-biz-unemployment-claims-20200317-uuiam6g2t5b6pczsouacogzenm-story.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eHartford Courant\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWe should mention—some states have broadened unemployment insurance eligibility to those who are quarantined or don’t have paid leave. That may have driven more Americans to seek unemployment insurance recently.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eThus far, companies have tried to tiptoe into the coronavirus crisis by furloughing and cutting down hours instead of outright layoffs. But economists say \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/call-it-a-layoff-a-furlough-or-a-cut-shift-americans-are-losing-work-11584550057?mod=hp_lead_pos1\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003elayoffs are inevitable\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eLooking ahead...\u003c/strong\u003etoday’s report covers last week; we won’t know the extent of this week’s damage until next Thursday.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: It?\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Jerome Powell testifying before Congress\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eU.S. Federal Reserve\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe Federal Reserve has \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2020/03/16/economy/federal-reserve-interest-rates-coronavirus/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etaken unprecedented action\u003c/a\u003e to stymie the economic fallout of COVID-19...and markets have responded with an unenthusiastic “k.” So what is the central bank’s role in all of this? \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eOver to Janet Yellen and Ben Bernanke for the answer. \u003c/strong\u003eIn a \u003ca href=\"https://www.ft.com/content/01f267a2-686c-11ea-a3c9-1fe6fedcca75?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eFinancial Times column\u003c/a\u003e yesterday, the former Fed chairs strung together highly technical words to say this: All the Fed can do is soften the inevitable blow.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBecause unlike 2008’s financial crisis, this one can’t be solved by monetary policy. Jerome Powell can’t exactly conjure vaccines or time machines.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eThat leaves the Fed responsible for 1) making any recession as short as possible and 2) limiting chain reactions.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHow that happens: \u003c/strong\u003eThe Fed needs to ensure responsible borrowers who fall on temporary hard times can tap into credit when needed. That insulates businesses from needing to lay off workers, which can force families to default on mortgages, which can lead to foreclosure, which can...you get it.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eKeeping borrowing like a gas station dinner—cheap and easy—is important. But \u003ca href=\"https://www.politico.com/news/2020/03/17/fed-battle-unclog-financial-markets-134282?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewithout Congressional backup\u003c/a\u003e, the Fed can only do so much.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" class=\"story-header-image\" src=\"https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC8yODEvb2ZmaWNlLmpwZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiIsImVkaXRzIjp7InJlc2l6ZSI6eyJ3aWR0aCI6MTAwMCwiaGVpZ2h0IjpudWxsfX19\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eFreshome\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, meal kit delivery service \u003ca href=\"https://finance.yahoo.com/news/blue-apron-stock-more-doubles-174529150.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eBlue Apron’s stock\u003c/a\u003e (+148%) was the seared salmon swimming upstream in a river of bummer. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe reason?\u003c/strong\u003e Restaurants are shutting down just as hoarding shoppers are clearing out some grocery stores. Blue Apron’s meal kits are looking more attractive as a sustenance option...and thus its stock is looking more attractive as a money option. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThe backstory:\u003c/strong\u003e Up until recently, Blue Apron was being shunted into the “promising startup that flamed out post-IPO” category with Grubhub and Uber. It went public in 2017 at a nearly $1.9 billion valuation, but even after this week's jump its market cap is down to $216 million. Last year, Blue Apron had to engineer a “reverse split” to support its plummeting stock price.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line: \u003c/strong\u003eThat maneuver makes \u003ca href=\"https://techcrunch.com/2020/03/18/why-is-blue-aprons-stock-skyrocketing/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eBlue Apron’s resurgence\u003c/a\u003e look surgier than it is, and it's unclear whether the company's shaky business pre-virus will find sturdier ground post-virus. Still, you couldn't imagine a better customer base for Blue Apron than a country of hermits. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\"
